moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nc3: The Vienna Opening, an unusual offshoot of the double-KP game. White hopes to advance his KBP forward before moving his KN so as to quickly open the K-side.
moves.2... Nf6: Black naturally attacks the unguarded KP.
moves.3. f4: Hoping to storm through with his K-side Pawns.
moves.3... d5: Thrusting his own center Pawns forward. This position can also arise by transposition from the Falkbeer Counter Gambit [1 P-K4 P-K4 2 P-KB4 P-Q4 3 N-QB3 N-KB3].
moves.4. fxe5: Removing one of Reinle's central Pawns.
moves.5. Qf3: Bearing his Q on the weak spot, KB7.
moves.5... Nc6: Threatening to capture the advanced Pawn and attack Neureiter's Queen.
moves.6... Nd4: Countering with a threat to the exposed White Queen.
moves.7... dxe4: Equalizing the material while protecting the Knight.
moves.8. Qc3: Getting out of the line of fire.
moves.8... Bb4: Cleverly attacking the Queen again. And 9 QxB??? would be answered by 9... NxP ch!!!, forking the R, Q and K.
moves.9. Qc4: 9 Q-KN3 would get the Queen out of danger, but 9... NxP ch would still fork K and R.
moves.9... Be6: White resigns. His Q has no flight square.
